content.title: Amaurosis Fugax
content.description: Transient monocular vision loss due to temporary retinal ischemia, typically from carotid artery embolism, representing a form of transient ischemic attack.
content.definition: Amaurosis fugax ('fleeting blindness') is painless, transient monocular vision loss lasting seconds to minutes, classically described as a 'shade coming down over the eye.' It typically results from embolism to the ophthalmic or central retinal artery from ipsilateral carotid plaque and is a high-risk TIA indicating need for urgent carotid evaluation.

classic_presentation: May be recurrent before permanent event
pathophysiology: Embolism from carotid plaque to ophthalmic artery
High risk for subsequent hemispheric stroke
differential_diagnosis: Giant cell arteritis (older patients, elevated ESR)
workup: CT or MR angiography if duplex equivocal

learning_objectives: Distinguish from other causes of transient vision loss
clinical_pearls: Amaurosis fugax is ipsilateral to the carotid lesion
Hollenhorst plaques (cholesterol emboli) visible on fundoscopy in 10-20%
Represents unstable plaque - 90-day stroke risk similar to hemispheric TIA
NASCET/ECST data support CEA for symptomatic 50-99% stenosis
Treat as medical emergency - workup within 24-48 hours
